replies.bodyText:
I tried to explain the reason for this change in the commit were it was introduced. Currently, "names" has plenty of different meanings through the run. I find it extremely ugly. While it is relatively correct in upstream, because DeckDueTreeNode has a very specific usage, what is done in AnkiDroid, using it in CardContentProvider makes no sens.
When the object is created, name is an array with a single element, the whole deck name. I.e. {"A::B::C"}.
Then, the name is splitted during the computation, and it becomes an array of part of the deck name. I.e. {"A", "B", "C"}
Then, each part of the name is removed from the array, starting by the top level deck part. I.e. {"B", "C"} (the node is then moved and declared to be a child of A), and then {"C"} (the node is then moved and declared to be a child of B, which is a child of A. At least assuming A::B exists)
When "getSubdeckName" is called, the array always contain a single element, so mName[0] and mName[mName.length - 1] are both correct. However, the value of mName[0] is "A::B::C", "A", "B" and finally "C" at the end of the run, which means that mName[0] is an incorect definition most of the time.
All of those discussion does not really matter as long as you keep the code as it is.
However, in order to have some code which make sens, my bigger PR state that:

we are going to save the full name and the array with the splitted name in two different final variables
instead of removing all elements of the array one by one (which is extremely inneficient by the way) we are just going to loop through the array's element (really, a single index, starting at 0 and increasing from 0 to the array size works just as well !)
to get the sub deck part, (i.e. the name displayed in the deck picker) we'll just get the last part of the array
